Conditional and Looping statements in Javascript

Arun v Â  in India
Tue Jun 15 2021
  • Condition
  • Looping
  • JavaScript

# Looping and Condition

Loops offer a quick and easy way to do something repeatedly. This chapter of the JavaScript Guide introduces the different iteration statements available to JavaScript.

You can think of a loop as a computerized version of the game where you tell someone to take X steps in one direction, then Y steps in another. For example, the idea "Go five steps to the east" could be expressed this way as a loop:

# If condition

if condition execute specific block of code if the condition is true

if (condition) {
	// code to be executed
}

example code

let x = 5;
let y = 5;
if (x == y) {
	console.log("condition satisfied");
}
// output
// condition satisfied

# If Else condition

if else condition execute specific block of code if the condition is true else the code in the else block will be executed.

if (condition) {
	// code to be executed if condition succeed
} else {
	// code to be executed if condition failed
}

example code

let x = 5;
let y = 5;
if (x < 5) {
	console.log("x is lesser than 5")
} else {
	console.log("x is not lesser than 5")
}
// output
// x is not lesser than 5

# If Else if condition

else if state is nothing but stacking more if statement under if statement, and we could have n number of else if statement under one another

if (condition1) {
	// code to run for first condition
} else if (condition2) {
	// code to run for second condition
} else if (condition3) {
	// code to run for third condition
} else {
	// code to run if no condition satisfied
}

example code

let num = 5;
if (num < 5) {
	console.log("num is lesser than 5");
} else if (num <= 5) {
	console.log("num is lesser than or equal to 5");
} else if (num > 5) {
	console.log("num is greater than 5");
} else {
	console.log("no condition matches");
}
// output
// num is lesser than or equal to 5

# Ternary operator

Ternary operator is the only JavaScript operator that takes three operands: a condition followed by a question mark (?), then an expression to execute if the condition is truthy followed by a colon (ðŸ˜ƒ, and finally the expression to execute if the condition is falsy. This operator is frequently used as a shortcut for the if statement.

const condition = 10 > 5
let result = condition ? "Condition satisfied" : "Condition failed"
console.log(result);
// output
// Condition satisfied

# Switch Case

The switch statement evaluates an expression, matching the expression's value to a case clause, and executes statements associated with that case, as well as statements in cases that follow the matching

switch(expression) {
  case x:
    // code block
    break;
  case y:
    // code block
    break;
  default:
    // code block
}

example code

let exp = 2;
switch (exp) {
	case 1:
		console.log("condition 1 matches");
		break;
	case 1:
		console.log("condition 2 matches");
		break;
	case 1:
		console.log("condition 3 matches");
		break;
	break:
		console.log("no condition satisfied");
		break;
}
// output
// condition 2 matches

# For loop

A for loop repeats until a specified condition evaluates to false. The JavaScript for loop is similar to the Java and C for loop.

for (let step = 0; step < 5; step++) {
	// Runs 5 times, with values of step 0 through 4.
	console.log("Step: ", step);
}
// output
// Step: 0
// Step: 1
// Step: 2
// Step: 3
// Step: 4

# Break in loop

break statement is used to break the loop any where in the process, this works on all loops

for (let step = 0; step < 5; step++) {
	if (step == 2) {
		console.log("Step: ", step);
	}
}
// output
// Step: 0
// Step: 1
// Step: 2

# While loop

A while statement executes its statements as long as a specified condition evaluates to true. A while statement looks as follows:

while (condition) {
	// execute code
}

example code

let x = 0;
while (x < 5) {
	console.log(x);
	x++;
}
// output
// 0
// 1
// 2
// 3
// 4

# Do While loop

do while statement is similar to while statement but in this case the loop will be executed at lease once and then check the condition

do {
	// code to execute
} while (condition);

example

let x = 0;
do {
	console.log(x);
} while (x < 3);
// output
// 0
// 1
// 2

# For In loop

The for...in statement iterates a specified variable over all the enumerable properties of an object. For each distinct property, JavaScript executes the specified statements. A for...in statement looks as follows:

for (key in object) {
	// statement
}

example code

let obj = {
	name: "some name"
	value: 324
}
for (key in obj) {
	console.log(`Key: ${key} Value: ${obj[key]}`);
}
// output
// Key: name Value: some name
// Key: value Value: 324

# For Of loop

The for...of statement creates a loop Iterating over iterable objects (including Array, Map, Set, arguments object and so on), invoking a custom iteration hook with statements to be executed for the value of each distinct property.

for (variable of object) {
	// statement
}

example code

const arr = [3, 5, 7];
arr.foo = 'hello';

for (let i in arr) {
   console.log(i); // logs "0", "1", "2", "foo"
}

for (let i of arr) {
   console.log(i); // logs 3, 5, 7
}
